A simple packaged Chrome ToDo app and a tutorial on how to get started...

A step-wise tutorial for building a Chrome app
A great tutorial for building a packaged Chrome app is available in this Google Code Lab and I used it as a starting point when I was working on my very first Chrome app, Simple TCP Client.

I will be referring to the Google code labs tutorial quite a lot -- BUT -- I found the example code in that code lab a little complex for a complete n00b such as myself, so in case you feel the same way, I hope you find the following tutorial useful.

Step 5 - Adding JavaScript Functionality

Previous Step: Creating the HTML View

In folder "js", create a file called "application.js" and add the js path to the end of your HTML body (window.html)...

<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8">
        <title>Chrome ToDo</title>
    </head>

    <body>
        <input id="text" placeholder="Type something here...">
        <button id="enter">Enter</button>
        <textarea id="output" rows="13" cols="25" readonly>Data log...</textarea>

        <script src="js/application.js"></script>
    </body>
</html>

For the JavaScript functionality, all we are going to do right now is to add anything typed in the input to the textarea when the button is pressed.

/**
 * Called on the "onload" event, sets event handlers for various elements.
 */
onload = function() {
    document.getElementById('enter').onclick = function() {
        // When the "Enter" button is pressed, text is read from the input
        // and updated in the textarea
        var txt = document.getElementById('output').value + '\r\n';
        txt += document.getElementById('text').value;
        document.getElementById('output').value = txt;
    };
};

Now, go to chrome://extensions and reload your app and launch your application.

There you go, a fully functional, albeit useless, Chrome app :monkey_face:

Step 4 - Creating the HTML View

Previous Step: The Background Script (background.js)

Let's create an HTML file, "window.html", which will contain a text field, a button and a text area.

"window.html" is loaded in background.js in the "onLaunched" listener in following statement:

chrome.app.window.create('window.html',
                         {'bounds': {'width': 250, 'height': 250}});

Now, let's create "window.html" with the following contents:

<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8">
        <title>Chrome ToDo</title>
    </head>

    <body>
        <input id="text" placeholder="Type something here...">
        <button id="enter">Enter</button>
        <textarea id="output" rows="13" cols="25" readonly>Data log...</textarea>
    </body>
</html>

Now you can load this intermediate app by going to chrome://extensions/ and using the "Load unpacked extension..." option. Your directory should look like this:

...or you can checkout the "sandbox" branch at the following commit (refer to this post if you need a quick reference to Git commands for doing this):

git checkout 1bbb8810055ab75f12b645e1ffd7c8ef54ea8162

At this point, it will look like this... I know, I know, its not too pretty at this point but we'll style it later with some CSS but for now we'll just focus on the functionality.

Step 3 - The Background Script (background.js)

Previous Step: Creating the Manifest (manifest.json)

In the manifest.json we created in the previous step, we configured the following path for background.js:

{
    //..........
    //..........
    "app": {
        "background": {
        "scripts": ["js/background.js"]
        }
    }
}

Create a folder "js" and create file background.js with the following content:

/**
 * 'onLaunched' listener
 */
chrome.app.runtime.onLaunched.addListener(function() {
    // We'll add more functionality later, for now we'll just create
    // the window with dimensions 250x250
    chrome.app.window.create('window.html',
                             {'bounds': {'width': 250, 'height': 250}});

});

This "listener" will be called when the application is launched, for now, all we are doing in this listener is creating the HTML view. For more details on a Chrome app's lifecycle, checkout this Google page or the following lifecycle diagram for quick reference:

Lifecycle Diagram from Google Chrome Developer portal

Now that we have the basic application framework setup, let's create a basic HTML view with some straight forward JavaScript in the next step to setup the application framework.

Step 2 - Creating the Manifest (manifest.json)

Previous Step: Getting Started

Creating a manifest is simple enough:

{
    "name": "Chrome ToDo",
    "description": "A simple to-do and note-taking Chrome app to accompany the tutorial at http://schaazzz.github.io/chrome_todo/",
    "version": "0.1",
    "app": {
        "background": {
        "scripts": ["js/background.js"]
        }
    }
}

You can download manifest.json here.
